meanings.def: to jump into water with your head and arms going in first
examples: dive (from/off something) (into something) We dived into the river to cool off.
dive off something He dived off the bridge.
dive in Sam walked to the deep end of the pool and dived in.
He dived head first into the water.
She dived from the top diving board.

meanings.def: to swim underwater wearing breathing equipment, collecting or looking at things
examples: to dive for pearls
The main purpose of his holiday to Greece was to go diving.

meanings.def: to go to a deeper level underwater
examples: The submarine dived to avoid being seen.
The whale dived as the harpoon struck it.

meanings.def: to go steeply down through the air
examples: The seagulls soared then dived.
The plane dived down to attack.
The plane suddenly dived from 10 000 feet to 5 000.
Unlike some birds, it does not dive vertically.

meanings.def: to move or jump quickly in a particular direction, especially to avoid something, to try to catch a ball, etc.
examples: dive for something We heard an explosion and dived for cover (= got into a place where we would be protected).
The goalie dived for the ball, but missed it.
+ adv./prep. It started to rain so we dived into the nearest cafe.
He dived headlong into the ditch.

meanings.def: to fall deliberately when somebody tackles you

examples: The share price dived from 75p to an all-time low of 50p.

meanings.def: a jump into deep water with your head first and your arms in front of you
examples: a spectacular high dive (= from high above the water)

meanings.def: an act of going underwater and swimming there with special equipment
examples: a dive to a depth of 18 metres
We did a deep dive to see if we could find the wreckage.

meanings.def: an act of suddenly flying downwards
examples: The pilot seemed to be having difficulty in pulling out of the dive.
The plane went into a steep dive.

meanings.def: a bar, music club, etc. that is cheap, and perhaps dark or dirty
examples: The band played in every smoky dive in town.

meanings.def: a deliberate fall that a player makes when somebody tackles them
examples: Kane's dive won England a penalty.

meanings.def: to suddenly move or jump forward to do something or reach somebody/something
examples: The goalkeeper made a dive for the ball.
Paul made a dive for the fridge to get a drink.
She made a dive for the door.
She made a running dive to get across the crevasse.
There would be a dive for the bar as soon as the show finished.
Profits really took a dive last year.
The market is volatile and profits could take a dive.
